to be run was that you would put it in a server and you would keep it running almost forever 6 months something like

to be able to change different parts of the system while the application was
running that is not how we run our systems in 2024 we run we have CI we
have containers our applications are immutable if you don't like your application or its operating system
or any of it you just put it in the bin and get a new one and so now Java had this problem
that it had all of this dynamism baked in that was completely and utterly
pointless and this is bad because the dynamism has a cost and so if you look at what a Java
application a non-trivial Java application does when it starts up
there's a a little bit of stuff that happens at build time generating the bik code putting it into uh an archive but
then there's a whole bunch of stuff that happens at runtime so at runtime it will
look at all the config it will do a whole bunch of loading and parsing it will then you know do a whole bunch of
class pass scanning it will do annotation Discovery it will use reflection to try and discover things
and then eventually you get this sort of meta model of the world and then eventually it will do things
like starting the thread pools and the io that's a lot of work before it's
ready to do anything and this is why people look like at languages like go and the worst bit is if you start
this application multiple times which you will do because you're running in
containers all of that work gets redone every single time this is really
annoying and it's really you know it's this sort of goldfish brain runtime
where it just doesn't remember the work that it's done and that's that's bad um and this
affects the speed quite significantly so as an example if you're using hibernate
hibernate does a whole bunch of work by reflection to try and wire independencies and really
any any non-trivial Library will do a lot of stuff with reflection so to
figure out what JTA Library you're using it will do a class forame which is expensive and then if that doesn't work
it will do another class forame and then it will do another one and then it will do another one and then it will do another one and it will do that until it
finds the right one and so that means if you're using a really obscure JTA
application it has to do so much work it will do 129 autowiring attempts before
it gives up every single startup and each one then ends up throwing
exceptions as well and this isn't just a JTA thing
this happens for lots of internal service bindings and then that has an impact at
startup but then it also has a KnockOn effect at runtime so the way method dispatching in
the jvm works is because it is quite Dynamic you will have an interface and
then you have multiple possible implementations of that interface and what the runtime will do
is it will have to look at each one before settling on the one that you're actually
using and so this is called megamorph
dispatching if you only have one implementation because you were able to get rid of all of the others at build
time then you can do monomorphic dispatching which is nice and
fast so quarcus really wanted to try and fix all of that waste
and so the the idea that they had was what if we initialize at build time
instead what if we still do all of that work because it has to happen but we only do it once and then that means that
if we do repeated starts it's efficient because it's just a tiny amount of work that's being repeated each time so
there's less waste which is cool and this isn't just a theoretical

could be like a person at a checkout it could be a computer whatever it is it's dealing with those incoming requests and
